reference.title: Guidelines for reference short descriptions
reference.shortdesc: Always use the <shortdesc> element in a reference topic. The short description must make sense both as the opening text of the topic and as pop-up text over a related link.

prolog.author: Guidelines owner: Michelle Carey, from Content Workgroup

section.title: Length
section.p: Use one to three sentences or up to 50 words.

section.title: What to say
section.p: Briefly describe what the reference item does, what it is, or what it is used for.

p.b: Example of an ineffective short description

dlentry.dd: DB2 Universal Database provides a COUNT command.

section.p: This short description states the obvious: that DB2 Universal Database provides this command. The short description does not tell users what the command is for.

p.b: Example of an effective short description

dlentry.dd: The COUNT command displays the current number of rows in the table. The rows are counted by the SQL SELECT COUNT(*) function.

section.p: This short description tells users what the command does and how the command works.

section.title: Phrasing
section.p: In most cases, use a complete sentence. You can use a sentence fragment only for a topic that is very short, such as an API topic and each of its subtopics. Use consistent phrasing across libraries and information centers so that your information can be seamlessly integrated with another product's information.

section.title: Examples of effective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. Highlighting in a short description will not appear in the pop-up text over a related link. autostop parameter Use the autostop parameter to direct a Q Apply program to stop automatically when there are no transactions to apply. Default: autostop=N.
ejbdeploy command
The command to generate deployment code. If this command is run without any arguments, it displays a list of arguments that can be run with the command.
Metadata object rules
Three types of rules apply to metadata objects: base rules, cube model completeness rules, and optimization rules. These rules ensure that each object is valid both in and out of the context of a cube model and that effective SQL queries can be written and optimized.
WSDL service document
The WSDL service document groups a set of related ports together.Â The WSDL service document is equivalent to a business service that is published to a UDDI registry.
MQReadXML function
The MQREADXML function returns XMLVARCHAR data from the MQSeries location that is specified by the receive-service option. The MQREADXML function does not remove messages from the queue that are associated with the receive-service option.
getValue method
Returns the value of the item specified.

section.title: Examples of ineffective short descriptions
section.p:
Topic titles are in bold. Short descriptions are in plain text. autostop parameter Lets you direct a Q Apply program to automatically stop when there are no transactions to apply.
Avoid phrasings such as Lets you . . . . in most IBM documentation. Also, the effective version of this example includes the default value.
APIs for developing enterprise bean tools Several APIs are made available for developers who are developing enterprise bean tools.
This short description restates the topic title. It does not add useful information. The passive voice also makes it difficult to identify where or how the APIs are made available. This topic might also be better suited as concept topic, not a reference topic.
Package com.ibm.faces.component Contains IBM JSF components.
This short description should provide more descriptive information about what the package contains and about the IBM JSF components.
Metadata mappings between the Data Warehouse Center and CWM XML objects and properties The following table shows how Data Warehouse Center objects map to CWM XML objects, based on the Common Warehouse Metamodel (CWM) Specification, Version 1.0.
Avoid adding a list or table lead-in sentence to a short description. You cannot add an <ol> or <ul> element inside a short description element. If you add a list or table lead-in sentence and then add the list or table to the next available element, the list or table will not be logically associated with the <shortdesc> element. Such a structure is semantically incorrect. You will not be able to reuse the list or table with its lead-in sentence. Also, this short description will not make sense in pop-up text for a related link.
